content: The "Maritime Law Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" is cited as the short title. It amends Subtitle VII of title 46, United States Code, by adding a new chapter on maritime law enforcement. The "Maritime Law Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" adds a new chapter on maritime law enforcement to Subtitle VII of title 46, United States Code. It prohibits transporting or aiding in the transportation of aliens on a covered vessel with the knowledge of their attempt to unlawfully enter the United States. Attempting or conspiring to commit this offense carries the same penalties as the violation itself. The "Maritime Law Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" prohibits transporting aliens on a vessel with the knowledge of their attempt to enter the US unlawfully. It is an affirmative defense to prove the alien was on board for a rescue at sea or due to an imminent threat. The defendant must inform the Coast Guard and comply with all orders. Violation of this law can result in imprisonment for 3 to 20 years or a fine. The "Maritime Law Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" imposes penalties for violations, including imprisonment for 3 to 20 years or fines up to $100,000. For serious bodily injury, the penalty is 7 to 30 years or fines up to $500,000. In cases of death, the penalty is 10 years to life or fines up to $1,000,000. Additionally, criminal forfeiture of any vessel used in the offense is mandated at sentencing.
